[et_pb_section fb_built=”1″ _builder_version=”3.22.3″ max_width_tablet=”” max_width_phone=”” max_width_last_edited=”on|desktop” module_alignment=”center” custom_padding=”0|0px|3px|0px|false|false”][et_pb_row _builder_version=”3.25″ custom_padding=”0px|||||”][et_pb_column type=”4_4″ _builder_version=”3.25″ custom_padding=”|||” custom_padding__hover=”|||”][et_pb_text _builder_version=”4.4.3″ text_font=”|600|||||||” text_text_color=”#151516″ text_orientation=”center” max_width=”70%” max_width_tablet=”” max_width_phone=”” max_width_last_edited=”on|desktop” module_alignment=”center” hover_enabled=”0″]

This is a simple dynamic warm-up arrangement where everyone on the team goes down and back at once.

[/et_pb_text][et_pb_image src=”https://ts-uploads.azureedge.net/marketing/2020/07/Full-Team-Down-Back-Warm-Up.png” align_tablet=”center” align_phone=”” align_last_edited=”on|desktop” _builder_version=”4.4.3″ max_width=”85%” max_width_tablet=”” max_width_phone=”” max_width_last_edited=”on|desktop” module_alignment=”center” hover_enabled=”0″][/et_pb_image][/et_pb_column][/et_pb_row][et_pb_row _builder_version=”3.25″ custom_padding=”4px|0px|33px|0px|false|false”][et_pb_column type=”4_4″ _builder_version=”3.25″ custom_padding=”|||” custom_padding__hover=”|||”][et_pb_text _builder_version=”4.4.3″ text_font=”|300|||||||” text_text_color=”#151516″ max_width=”70%” max_width_tablet=”” max_width_phone=”” max_width_last_edited=”on|desktop” module_alignment=”center” hover_enabled=”0″]

Set Up

This variation of the general dynamic warm-up is extremely simple and requires almost no set up at all. Basically have the players line up on one side of the grid and they all move down and back together.

[/et_pb_text][et_pb_text _builder_version=”4.4.3″ text_font=”|300|||||||” text_text_color=”#151516″ max_width=”70%” max_width_tablet=”” max_width_phone=”” max_width_last_edited=”on|desktop” module_alignment=”center” hover_enabled=”0″]

How It Works

Players perform dynamic movements to the cone on the opposite side, then perform a recovery run by jogging back to the start. (They can also perform dynamic movements back instead) Dynamic movements can include things like:

  • Forward Jogging
  • Backward Jogging
  • Side Shuffles
  • Skipping With Backward Arm-circles
  • Backward Skipping
  • Sideways Skipping
  • Grapevine/Carioca
  • Sideways Jumping Jacks
  • High Kicks
  • Inside Touches
  • High Knees
  • Butt Kickers
  • Two Foot Jumps
  • Single Leg Hops
  • Leap Frog
  • Forward Lunges
  • Backwards Lunges
  • Sideways Lunges
  • Lunges With A Twist
  • Knee To Chest Stretch
  • Quad Stretch
  • Toe Touches
  • Bear Crawls
  • Crab Walk
  • 50% Jog
  • 75% Run
  • 100% Sprint

 

[/et_pb_text][et_pb_text _builder_version=”3.27.4″ text_font=”|300|||||||” text_text_color=”#151516″ max_width=”70%” max_width_tablet=”” max_width_phone=”” max_width_last_edited=”on|desktop” module_alignment=”center”]

Coaching Points

Once players learn the basic locomotions they can perform these exercises on their own without the help of a coach. This can potentially afford a coach some extra time while setting up other drills. 

By the end of the warm-up the players should have broken a sweat. This ensures that the body is prepared for the activities to come and reduces the risk of injury.

[/et_pb_text][/et_pb_column][/et_pb_row][/et_pb_section]

excerpt.rendered: This is a simple dynamic warm-up arrangement where everyone on the team goes down and back at once.
